97 n.9 rightly points out, Deucalion and Pyrrha come first. Their love, as a married couple, is portrayed as devotion and mutual dependency rather than a wild, erotic impulse; Apollo's unrequited passion for Daphne is of quite a different order

note: the emblematic status of the Apollo and Daphne story is often commented on by critics: e.g. Otis (1970), 78-9; Curran (1978), 231; Nagle (1988a), 32.
title: 1.689-712), Alpheus and Arethusa (5.572-641), Glaucus and Scylla (13.900-14.74). There are many variations on the theme, too: e.g. Hippomenes and Atalanta (10.560-680), where the chase of love is 'formalised' into a running race, and Atalanta, herself feeling the stirrings of love, is half-willing to be beaten by Hippomenes; and Circe and Picus (14.320-96), where it is the male, Picus, who is the target of the lovelorn Circe, and who is the subject of metamorphosis
